t: Isaiah 33
The Judgment of God

Woe*pn to you, O destroyer, While*ln you were not destroyed; And*ln he who is treacherous, while others*i did not deal treacherously with him. As*ln soon as you finish destroying, you will be destroyed; As*ln soon as you cease to deal treacherously, others*i will deal treacherously with you.
O*ln Lord,*s be gracious to us; we have waited for You. Be*ln their strength every morning, Our*ln salvation also in the time of distress.
At*ln the sound of the tumult peoples flee; At*ln the lifting up of Yourself nations disperse.
Your*ln spoil is gathered as*i the caterpillar gathers; As*ln locusts rushing about men rush about on it.
The*ln Lord*s is exalted, for He dwells on high; He*ln has filled Zion with justice and righteousness.
And*ln He will be the stability of your times, A*ln wealth of salvation, wisdom and knowledge; The*ln fear of the Lord*s is his treasure.
Behold,*ln their brave men cry in the streets, The*ln ambassadors of peace weep bitterly.
The*ln highways are desolate, the traveler has ceased, He*ln has broken the covenant, he has despised the cities, He*ln has no regard for man.
The*ln land mourns and*i pines away, Lebanon*ln is shamed and*i withers; Sharon*ln is like a desert plain, And*ln Bashan and Carmel lose their*i foliage.*i
“Now*ln I will arise,” says the Lord,*s “Now*ln I will be exalted, now I will be lifted up.
You*ln have conceived chaff, you will give birth to stubble; My*ln breath will consume you like a fire.
The*ln peoples will be burned to lime, Like*ln cut thorns which are burned in the fire.
“You*ln who are far away, hear what I have done; And*ln you who are near, acknowledge My might.”
Sinners*ln in Zion are terrified; Trembling*ln has seized the godless. “Who*ln among us can live with the consuming fire? Who*ln among us can live with continual burning?”

He*ln who walks righteously and speaks with sincerity, He*ln who rejects unjust gain And*ln shakes his hands so that they hold no bribe; He*ln who stops his ears from hearing about bloodshed And*ln shuts his eyes from looking upon evil;
He*ln will dwell on the heights, His*ln refuge will be the impregnable rock; His*ln bread will be given him,*i His*ln water will be sure.
Your*ln eyes will see the King in His beauty; They*ln will behold a far-distant land.
Your*ln heart will meditate on terror: “Where*ln is he who counts? Where*ln is he who weighs? Where*ln is he who counts the towers?”
You*ln will no longer see a fierce people, A*ln people of unintelligible speech which no one comprehends, Of*ln a stammering tongue which no one understands.

Look*ln upon Zion, the city of our appointed feasts; Your*ln eyes will see Jerusalem, an undisturbed habitation, A*ln tent which will not be folded; Its*ln stakes will never be pulled up, Nor*ln any of its cords be torn apart.
But*ln there the majestic One,*i the Lord,*s will be for us A*ln place of rivers and*i wide canals On*ln which no boat with oars will go, And*ln on which no mighty ship will pass—
For*ln the Lord*s is our judge, The*ln Lord*s is our lawgiver, The*ln Lord*s is our king; He*ln will save us—
Your*ln tackle hangs slack; It*ln cannot hold the base of its mast firmly, Nor*ln spread out the sail. Then*ln the prey of an abundant spoil will be divided; The*ln lame will take the plunder.
And*ln no resident will say, “I am sick”; The*ln people who dwell there will be forgiven their*i iniquity.
